Bund yields not reflecting the equities optimism: - Bund yields are falling by more than equities would justify. - From the demand side, we may have more investors seeking safe havens from market turmoil, whilst from a supply perspective, we see very little net issuance in October versus other months. - 10y Bund yield fell to 2.56%, lowest level since July mid, on renewed trade tensions and rising Fed cut bets.

meaning: Qualifies something as large or important, e.g., major purchases or major macro shifts.
notes: Generic adjective; context is economic but meaning is standard.
examples: Retail sales in the UK jumped 1.5% YoY in September 2025, accelerating from a 0.7% increase in August and marking the highest gain since April. The GfK Consumer Confidence Index for the UK rose to -17 in October 2025 from -19 in September, beating expectations for a decline to -20 as shoppers geared up for the Black Friday sales despite concerns over the upcoming Budget. The gain was mainly driven by a four-point rise in the major purchase index, which measures confidence in buying big-ticket items, to -12. Expectations for the general economic situation over the next 12 months also climbed two points to -30, while the outlook for personal finances slipped one point to +3.

Historically, gold’s share in large institutional and sovereign portfolios has remained remarkably stable — typically in the range of 8–12% for diversified funds and 3–5% for traditional multi-asset portfolios. Despite major macro shifts over the past decade — from negative interest rates to post-pandemic tightening — the structural allocation to gold has not changed materially. However, the current global investment climate presents a notably different backdrop: • Elevated geopolitical uncertainty (U.S.–China trade realignments, Middle East tensions, and rising nuclear risk rhetoric) • Persistently high fiscal deficits across major economies, leading to currency debasement fears • Increasing volatility in both equity and bond markets due to diverging monetary policies • Declining real yields and renewed expectations of monetary easing in 2026 Given these factors, even a marginal portfolio realignment — an increase of just 2–5% in gold allocation — across institutional or high-net-worth portfolios could generate significant incremental demand. For context, every 1% shift in global asset allocation toward gold represents hundreds of tonnes of additional demand, which historically has had a multiplicative price impact due to the market’s limited float and thin elasticity. Estimated target for end-2025 Putting all this together, a reasonable base-case target could be in the US $4,200-$4,600/oz range by end-2025, assuming no major shock.

meaning: Refers to the industrial production sector that produces goods (autos, machinery, etc.), often as a component of macro data like PMI or industrial production.
notes: Economic-sector term; widely used beyond finance.
examples: China Industrial production came weaker than expected: - October value added of industry growth slowed to 4.9% YoY, down from 6.5%. - This came in below expectations for a smaller decline, marking the lowest growth since August 2024. - The year-to-date growth edged down 0.1pp to 6.1% YoY as a result. - By industry, we continue to see the same themes outperform. - Auto manufacturing (16.8%) and rail, ships, and aeroplane manufacturing (15.2%) remain clear outperformers. - We’re still seeing strong growth in semiconductor (17.7%), industrial robot (17.9%), and service robot (12.8%) production.

Eurozone Composite PMI hits 1.5yrs high: - The HCOB Eurozone Composite PMI rose to 52.2 in October of 2025 from 51.2 in the previous month, ahead of market expectations of 51 to reflect the sharpest pace of expansion since May 2024. - The expansion was carried by the services sector (52.6 vs 51.3 in September), which rose to a fresh one-year high, while the manufacturing sector unexpectedly avoided a contraction (50 vs 49.8). - New orders accelerated in the period with strong support from domestic clients, offsetting a fresh drop in export business. - The signals drove firms to increase their staffing levels to erase last month's slight decrease. - Likewise, backlogs of work refrained from dropping from for the first time since April 2023. - Input cost inflation eased for a second month, although output charges accelerated the most in seven. - Looking forward, business confidence waned to a five-month low.

meaning: Refers either to financial markets (bonds, equities, FX, rates) or to the aggregate reaction/pricing by participants; sometimes also to expectations or consensus (e.g., ‘market expectations’).
notes: Everyday word but here used in the finance/economics sense of trading venues and pricing.
examples: In the US session today, all eyes will be on the September US NFP report and the US Jobless Claims. The NFP is expected at 50K vs 22K prior with the Unemployment Rate remaining unchanged at 4.3%. The Average Hourly Earnings Y/Y is expected at 3.7% vs 3.7% prior, while the M/M figure is seen at 0.3% vs 0.3% prior. Needless to say, this is very old news by now but it might still matter for the market given that we don't get any other NFP report until December 16, which is unfortunately after the December FOMC meeting. The December cut probabilities now stand at just 25% following the update from the BLS that we will get the November NFP only on December 16. We should also get the most recent Jobless Claims data alongside the NFP report, and those might actually be more important. The Initial Claims are expected at 230K, while the Continuing Claims are seen at 1951K.

Japan Q3 GDP contracted less than expected: - Japan’s GDP contracted 0.4% qoq in Q3 2025, reversing an upwardly revised 0.6% growth in Q2 but performing slightly better than market expectations of a 0.6% decline, preliminary data showed. - It was the first quarterly drop since Q1 2024, reflecting subdued private consumption (0.1% vs 0.4%) amid lingering cost pressures, particularly elevated rice prices and rising utility bills. - Net trade also contributed negatively (-0.2 ppts), with exports (-1.2% vs 2.3%) falling faster than imports (-0.1% vs 1.3%) after Washington imposed a 15% baseline tariff on most Japanese goods in September. - Still, government spending (0.5% vs 0.1%) and business investment (1.0% vs 0.8%) recorded their strongest gains in five quarters, supported by front-loaded public works and corporate upgrades to production capacity.

meaning: Plural of market, referring collectively to financial markets or specific segments (rates, swaps, government bonds) and their behavior or stress.
notes: Again generic word, but usage is clearly financial.
examples: Euro rates: Risks around Dutch pension reforms The Dutch central bank acknowledges risks to interest rates linked to the 1 January 2026 transition of Dutch pension funds, but also sees mitigants to prevent market stress. The 10s30s has more room to steepen from a structural perspective, but we don't fully discount the probability of seeing some flattening in January. Dutch pension reforms bring volatility to long end, but market stress unlikely The 10s30s curve has stabilised to around 25bp over the past month, but with the Dutch pension fund reforms on our doorstep, we doubt that stability can hold. The Dutch central bank (DNB) published a piece that highlights the risks to markets given the significant flows anticipated. According to DNB, market analysts anticipate funds will reduce their government bond and swap holdings with maturities of more than 25 years by €100bn to €150bn. Without further specification, DNB suggests that these estimates correspond to approximately the average flows in swap markets for a regular month.

French consumer confidence showed some improvement today. - Consumer confidence in France rose to 90 in October from an upwardly revised 88 in September, marking the highest level since April. - Households were less pessimistic about their financial outlook, with expectations improving to -11 from -14 in September and views on their past situation slightly better at -20 from -21. - Saving sentiment also strengthened, as both current (23 vs 20) and expected (19 vs 17) saving capacity increased, while savings intentions reached a four-month high of 44.

meaning: Modal verb expressing possibility or reduced certainty about future economic or policy outcomes.
notes: Standard English modal; context is macro/markets but meaning is generic.
examples: Q3 GDP data keeps China solidly on pace to reach this year's "around 5%" growth target, and it may reduce the urgency for more immediate action.

GDP growth slowed by less than expected in 3Q25 - China's GDP grew by 4.8% YoY (missing the5% target) in the third quarter, slowing for a second consecutive quarter from the 5.2% growth in the second quarter. - Still, the economy managed to beat expectations for a steeper decline. - Through the first three quarters of the year, China's economy has grown by 5.2% YoY. - By industry, China's tertiary industry drove growth in 3Q25 with a 5.4% YoY growth, comfortably outpacing growth in the secondary (4.2%) and primary (4.0%) industries. - The better-than-expected GDP data was likely thanks in part to a strong bounce-back in industrial production to 6.5% YoY in September, which is benefiting from resilient external demand. - Yet, soft monthly activity data throughout the quarter suggests that a favourable boost from the GDP deflator may have contributed to this performance.

meaning: Refers to scheduled gatherings of policymakers or leaders (e.g., Fed meeting, Xi–Trump meeting, Fourth Plenum meetings) that can act as catalysts for market moves.
notes: Generic word; in trading chats it’s important as an event risk, but meaning is standard.
examples: Fourth Plenum, Xi-Trump summit, and PBOC are potential catalysts to watch The stronger-than-expected third-quarter data mean that, barring a dramatic deceleration in 4Q, China will likely manage to reach its full-year target of "around 5%" growth. Domestically, the Fourth Plenum meetings this week are likely to give some insights into China's 15th Five-Year Plan. The full text will not be available until the plan is formally approved at the Two Sessions next year. This plan will offer some insight into how China plans to navigate an increasingly difficult external environment. Investors will likely watch closely for signs of concrete steps to boost consumption, as well as areas for tech development and focus. The long-awaited and high-stakes Xi-Trump meeting next week in South Korea looks likely to take place despite the recent escalations in US-China friction. Language and signalling suggest that both sides would prefer to reach some sort of agreement to continue the current uneasy truce rather than see a re-escalation back to, or beyond, this year's peak tensions in April-May. The odds of miscalculation remain, though, representing a potential downside risk to the outlook. While we see a diminishing marginal impact from further tariff hikes, the prospects of non-tariff escalations represent a notable uncertainty.

USD: Dollar softer, but short term trend unclear The dollar is a little softer as short-dated US rates sit at their lows for the year. Last night's release of the Fed's Beige Book suggests the Fed will have enough evidence to cut rates at the end of the month – even if official data releases remain suspended because of the government shutdown. Here, betting markets expect the government to remain closed into November. The hottest topic for financial markets right now is US-China relations ahead of some key dates. Presidents Trump and Xi are meant to be meeting on the sidelines of the APEC summit in Korea in the 29-31 October window. This is before the 10 November deadline for the 90-day truce on tariffs, where no extension would see US tariffs on China revert to 145%.

China CPI inflation edged up but remained in deflation China's CPI inflation edged up in September, but the economy remained in deflation. The main reason is a continued slide in food prices down to -4.4% YoY, a 20-month low. This is, in part, base effect-driven, as MoM prices actually picked up 0.7%. The primary culprit has been pork (-17%), which is currently in a downward trend and likely to continue dragging food inflation for several more months. On a YoY basis, we continued to see notable drags from vegetable (-13.7%), egg (-11.9%), and fruit (-4.2%) prices despite MoM gains for each of these categories. The drag from these categories may persist in October, but should ease from November onward, helping to support a turnaround of food inflation. The silver lining in the data was that non-food inflation picked up to 0.7% YoY, up for a fourth consecutive month despite a -0.1% MoM dip.

ING: Our first look at the next Five-Year Plan shows China staying the course The communiqué following China's Fourth Plenum has given markets a first look at the priorities for the 15th Five-Year Plan. The key focus for policymakers looks little changed, as modernisation, innovation, self-sufficiency, and boosting domestic demand feature prominently. China's next Five-Year Plan continues to focus on key themes and moderate growth The goal to have per capita GDP reach the level of a "moderately developed economy" was also mentioned, which, in conjunction with previous goals to double the size of the economy between 2020 and 2035, continues to imply an emphasis on maintaining growth of 4-5% in the coming decade. Industrial modernisation, tech self-sufficiency and innovation feature prominently We have seen a bit of a shift in the order of priorities compared to the 14th Five-Year Plan. Following the broader economic and social development targets, building a modern industrial system and strengthening the real economy was the first broad category mentioned, followed by technological self-sufficiency and innovation, and then building a strong domestic market.

meaning: Negation, indicating absence or lack (e.g., no major shock, no extension of truce).
notes: Generic English negator.
examples: Historically, gold’s share in large institutional and sovereign portfolios has remained remarkably stable — typically in the range of 8–12% for diversified funds and 3–5% for traditional multi-asset portfolios. Despite major macro shifts over the past decade — from negative interest rates to post-pandemic tightening — the structural allocation to gold has not changed materially. However, the current global investment climate presents a notably different backdrop: • Elevated geopolitical uncertainty (U.S.–China trade realignments, Middle East tensions, and rising nuclear risk rhetoric) • Persistently high fiscal deficits across major economies, leading to currency debasement fears • Increasing volatility in both equity and bond markets due to diverging monetary policies • Declining real yields and renewed expectations of monetary easing in 2026 Given these factors, even a marginal portfolio realignment — an increase of just 2–5% in gold allocation — across institutional or high-net-worth portfolios could generate significant incremental demand. For context, every 1% shift in global asset allocation toward gold represents hundreds of tonnes of additional demand, which historically has had a multiplicative price impact due to the market’s limited float and thin elasticity. Estimated target for end-2025 Putting all this together, a reasonable base-case target could be in the US $4,200-$4,600/oz range by end-2025, assuming no major shock.

USD: Dollar softer, but short term trend unclear The dollar is a little softer as short-dated US rates sit at their lows for the year. Last night's release of the Fed's Beige Book suggests the Fed will have enough evidence to cut rates at the end of the month – even if official data releases remain suspended because of the government shutdown. Here, betting markets expect the government to remain closed into November. The hottest topic for financial markets right now is US-China relations ahead of some key dates. Presidents Trump and Xi are meant to be meeting on the sidelines of the APEC summit in Korea in the 29-31 October window. This is before the 10 November deadline for the 90-day truce on tariffs, where no extension would see US tariffs on China revert to 145%.

meaning: Temporal adverb referring to the current point in time, often relative to current market pricing or probabilities.
notes: Generic temporal term; used to describe current market state.
examples: In the US session today, all eyes will be on the September US NFP report and the US Jobless Claims. The NFP is expected at 50K vs 22K prior with the Unemployment Rate remaining unchanged at 4.3%. The Average Hourly Earnings Y/Y is expected at 3.7% vs 3.7% prior, while the M/M figure is seen at 0.3% vs 0.3% prior. Needless to say, this is very old news by now but it might still matter for the market given that we don't get any other NFP report until December 16, which is unfortunately after the December FOMC meeting. The December cut probabilities now stand at just 25% following the update from the BLS that we will get the November NFP only on December 16. We should also get the most recent Jobless Claims data alongside the NFP report, and those might actually be more important. The Initial Claims are expected at 230K, while the Continuing Claims are seen at 1951K.

meaning: Used in its temporal/quantitative sense, e.g., describing averages or behavior across a period or amount ("over the past month", "over a regular month"), not as a pricing preposition.
notes: Generic English usage; appears inside macro commentary rather than as trading slang like 'over the figure'.
examples: Retail sales in the UK jumped 1.5% YoY in September 2025, accelerating from a 0.7% increase in August and marking the highest gain since April. The GfK Consumer Confidence Index for the UK rose to -17 in October 2025 from -19 in September, beating expectations for a decline to -20 as shoppers geared up for the Black Friday sales despite concerns over the upcoming Budget. The gain was mainly driven by a four-point rise in the major purchase index, which measures confidence in buying big-ticket items, to -12. Expectations for the general economic situation over the next 12 months also climbed two points to -30, while the outlook for personal finances slipped one point to +3.

Euro rates: Risks around Dutch pension reforms The Dutch central bank acknowledges risks to interest rates linked to the 1 January 2026 transition of Dutch pension funds, but also sees mitigants to prevent market stress. The 10s30s has more room to steepen from a structural perspective, but we don't fully discount the probability of seeing some flattening in January. Dutch pension reforms bring volatility to long end, but market stress unlikely The 10s30s curve has stabilised to around 25bp over the past month, but with the Dutch pension fund reforms on our doorstep, we doubt that stability can hold. The Dutch central bank (DNB) published a piece that highlights the risks to markets given the significant flows anticipated. According to DNB, market analysts anticipate funds will reduce their government bond and swap holdings with maturities of more than 25 years by €100bn to €150bn. Without further specification, DNB suggests that these estimates correspond to approximately the average flows in swap markets for a regular month.

meaning: Refers to previous time periods or historical values (e.g., 'over the past month', 'views on their past situation'), used to compare current data to earlier conditions.
notes: Standard temporal adjective; context is economic data but meaning is generic.
examples: French consumer confidence showed some improvement today. - Consumer confidence in France rose to 90 in October from an upwardly revised 88 in September, marking the highest level since April. - Households were less pessimistic about their financial outlook, with expectations improving to -11 from -14 in September and views on their past situation slightly better at -20 from -21. - Saving sentiment also strengthened, as both current (23 vs 20) and expected (19 vs 17) saving capacity increased, while savings intentions reached a four-month high of 44.

examples: Powell Q&A:A risk that slow pass-through of tariff start to look like persistent inflation - A risk that slow pass-through of tariffs starts to look like persistent inflation. - The labor market has demonstrated significant downside risk. - As risk come more into about policy needed to move to being more neutral. - If Fed moves too quickly in May leave the inflation job unfinished. - Data since the July meeting shows labor market has softened considerably. - Will not try to pinpoint breakeven rate of employment. Standard error itself is perhaps 50 K. - Breakeven rate of job growth has come down a great deal. - Range of plausible numbers could go to negative given the 50K standard error - The fact the unemployment rate has barely moved is quite remarkable. - Research points to longer legs for policy to influence jobs and inflation.

meaning: Refers to the level or movement of prices of goods and services in the economy (e.g., food, rice, utilities) as captured in inflation data, not asset prices.
notes: Economic context (CPI, cost pressures) but meaning is the generic notion of prices of items.
examples: Japan Q3 GDP contracted less than expected: - Japan’s GDP contracted 0.4% qoq in Q3 2025, reversing an upwardly revised 0.6% growth in Q2 but performing slightly better than market expectations of a 0.6% decline, preliminary data showed. - It was the first quarterly drop since Q1 2024, reflecting subdued private consumption (0.1% vs 0.4%) amid lingering cost pressures, particularly elevated rice prices and rising utility bills. - Net trade also contributed negatively (-0.2 ppts), with exports (-1.2% vs 2.3%) falling faster than imports (-0.1% vs 1.3%) after Washington imposed a 15% baseline tariff on most Japanese goods in September. - Still, government spending (0.5% vs 0.1%) and business investment (1.0% vs 0.8%) recorded their strongest gains in five quarters, supported by front-loaded public works and corporate upgrades to production capacity.

China CPI inflation edged up but remained in deflation China's CPI inflation edged up in September, but the economy remained in deflation. The main reason is a continued slide in food prices down to -4.4% YoY, a 20-month low. This is, in part, base effect-driven, as MoM prices actually picked up 0.7%. The primary culprit has been pork (-17%), which is currently in a downward trend and likely to continue dragging food inflation for several more months. On a YoY basis, we continued to see notable drags from vegetable (-13.7%), egg (-11.9%), and fruit (-4.2%) prices despite MoM gains for each of these categories. The drag from these categories may persist in October, but should ease from November onward, helping to support a turnaround of food inflation. The silver lining in the data was that non-food inflation picked up to 0.7% YoY, up for a fourth consecutive month despite a -0.1% MoM dip.

The most important comment from US Trade Representative Greer Yesterday, we got a strong rebound in the US stock markets. The first 50% of the rally might have started due to CNBC announcing that US Trade Representative Greer would appear on TV. But let's also say that it might have been just a technical dip-buying move as prices fell into the Friday's lows at the cash open. Now, Greer didn't really say anything new but he did deliver two key comments: - We always watch the stock and bond markets. - We want to make sure the market responds to appropriate info. That second comment is key. It sounds like they don't want the market to think this is going to be another April. They want the market to keep expecting a de-escalation.

meaning: Refers to industrial or economic output (e.g., industrial production, manufacturing of autos, semiconductors, robots), used as a macro indicator.
notes: Macro-economic usage; traders use it as a data point but the word itself is generic.
examples: Japan Q3 GDP contracted less than expected: - Japan’s GDP contracted 0.4% qoq in Q3 2025, reversing an upwardly revised 0.6% growth in Q2 but performing slightly better than market expectations of a 0.6% decline, preliminary data showed. - It was the first quarterly drop since Q1 2024, reflecting subdued private consumption (0.1% vs 0.4%) amid lingering cost pressures, particularly elevated rice prices and rising utility bills. - Net trade also contributed negatively (-0.2 ppts), with exports (-1.2% vs 2.3%) falling faster than imports (-0.1% vs 1.3%) after Washington imposed a 15% baseline tariff on most Japanese goods in September. - Still, government spending (0.5% vs 0.1%) and business investment (1.0% vs 0.8%) recorded their strongest gains in five quarters, supported by front-loaded public works and corporate upgrades to production capacity.

China Industrial production came weaker than expected: - October value added of industry growth slowed to 4.9% YoY, down from 6.5%. - This came in below expectations for a smaller decline, marking the lowest growth since August 2024. - The year-to-date growth edged down 0.1pp to 6.1% YoY as a result. - By industry, we continue to see the same themes outperform. - Auto manufacturing (16.8%) and rail, ships, and aeroplane manufacturing (15.2%) remain clear outperformers. - We’re still seeing strong growth in semiconductor (17.7%), industrial robot (17.9%), and service robot (12.8%) production.

GDP growth slowed by less than expected in 3Q25 - China's GDP grew by 4.8% YoY (missing the5% target) in the third quarter, slowing for a second consecutive quarter from the 5.2% growth in the second quarter. - Still, the economy managed to beat expectations for a steeper decline. - Through the first three quarters of the year, China's economy has grown by 5.2% YoY. - By industry, China's tertiary industry drove growth in 3Q25 with a 5.4% YoY growth, comfortably outpacing growth in the secondary (4.2%) and primary (4.0%) industries. - The better-than-expected GDP data was likely thanks in part to a strong bounce-back in industrial production to 6.5% YoY in September, which is benefiting from resilient external demand. - Yet, soft monthly activity data throughout the quarter suggests that a favourable boost from the GDP deflator may have contributed to this performance.

Fourth Plenum, Xi-Trump summit, and PBOC are potential catalysts to watch The stronger-than-expected third-quarter data mean that, barring a dramatic deceleration in 4Q, China will likely manage to reach its full-year target of "around 5%" growth. Domestically, the Fourth Plenum meetings this week are likely to give some insights into China's 15th Five-Year Plan. The full text will not be available until the plan is formally approved at the Two Sessions next year. This plan will offer some insight into how China plans to navigate an increasingly difficult external environment. Investors will likely watch closely for signs of concrete steps to boost consumption, as well as areas for tech development and focus. The long-awaited and high-stakes Xi-Trump meeting next week in South Korea looks likely to take place despite the recent escalations in US-China friction. Language and signalling suggest that both sides would prefer to reach some sort of agreement to continue the current uneasy truce rather than see a re-escalation back to, or beyond, this year's peak tensions in April-May. The odds of miscalculation remain, though, representing a potential downside risk to the outlook. While we see a diminishing marginal impact from further tariff hikes, the prospects of non-tariff escalations represent a notable uncertainty.
Q3 GDP data keeps China solidly on pace to reach this year's "around 5%" growth target, and it may reduce the urgency for more immediate action.

meaning: Used in two senses: (1) 'real economy' meaning the non-financial, productive side of the economy; (2) 'real yields' meaning inflation-adjusted interest rates.
notes: Both senses are standard in macro/markets and differ from the everyday 'real vs fake'.
examples: ING: Our first look at the next Five-Year Plan shows China staying the course The communiqué following China's Fourth Plenum has given markets a first look at the priorities for the 15th Five-Year Plan. The key focus for policymakers looks little changed, as modernisation, innovation, self-sufficiency, and boosting domestic demand feature prominently. China's next Five-Year Plan continues to focus on key themes and moderate growth The goal to have per capita GDP reach the level of a "moderately developed economy" was also mentioned, which, in conjunction with previous goals to double the size of the economy between 2020 and 2035, continues to imply an emphasis on maintaining growth of 4-5% in the coming decade. Industrial modernisation, tech self-sufficiency and innovation feature prominently We have seen a bit of a shift in the order of priorities compared to the 14th Five-Year Plan. Following the broader economic and social development targets, building a modern industrial system and strengthening the real economy was the first broad category mentioned, followed by technological self-sufficiency and innovation, and then building a strong domestic market.

Historically, gold’s share in large institutional and sovereign portfolios has remained remarkably stable — typically in the range of 8–12% for diversified funds and 3–5% for traditional multi-asset portfolios. Despite major macro shifts over the past decade — from negative interest rates to post-pandemic tightening — the structural allocation to gold has not changed materially. However, the current global investment climate presents a notably different backdrop: • Elevated geopolitical uncertainty (U.S.–China trade realignments, Middle East tensions, and rising nuclear risk rhetoric) • Persistently high fiscal deficits across major economies, leading to currency debasement fears • Increasing volatility in both equity and bond markets due to diverging monetary policies • Declining real yields and renewed expectations of monetary easing in 2026 Given these factors, even a marginal portfolio realignment — an increase of just 2–5% in gold allocation — across institutional or high-net-worth portfolios could generate significant incremental demand. For context, every 1% shift in global asset allocation toward gold represents hundreds of tonnes of additional demand, which historically has had a multiplicative price impact due to the market’s limited float and thin elasticity. Estimated target for end-2025 Putting all this together, a reasonable base-case target could be in the US $4,200-$4,600/oz range by end-2025, assuming no major shock.
Still bullish so far given that real yields low and dollar not yet over‑tight, gold’s safe‑haven appeal remains intact

meaning: Refers to structural or regulatory changes, particularly Dutch pension system reforms that alter asset allocation and thus affect long-end rates.
notes: Policy-reform is generic, but here it has specific market implications for bond/swap flows.
examples: Euro rates: Risks around Dutch pension reforms The Dutch central bank acknowledges risks to interest rates linked to the 1 January 2026 transition of Dutch pension funds, but also sees mitigants to prevent market stress. The 10s30s has more room to steepen from a structural perspective, but we don't fully discount the probability of seeing some flattening in January. Dutch pension reforms bring volatility to long end, but market stress unlikely The 10s30s curve has stabilised to around 25bp over the past month, but with the Dutch pension fund reforms on our doorstep, we doubt that stability can hold. The Dutch central bank (DNB) published a piece that highlights the risks to markets given the significant flows anticipated. According to DNB, market analysts anticipate funds will reduce their government bond and swap holdings with maturities of more than 25 years by €100bn to €150bn. Without further specification, DNB suggests that these estimates correspond to approximately the average flows in swap markets for a regular month.

meaning: Describes persistence of a condition or status (e.g., sectors remain outperformers, CPI to remain at a level).
notes: Generic verb of state; used in economic commentary but not with a special financial meaning.
examples: China Industrial production came weaker than expected: - October value added of industry growth slowed to 4.9% YoY, down from 6.5%. - This came in below expectations for a smaller decline, marking the lowest growth since August 2024. - The year-to-date growth edged down 0.1pp to 6.1% YoY as a result. - By industry, we continue to see the same themes outperform. - Auto manufacturing (16.8%) and rail, ships, and aeroplane manufacturing (15.2%) remain clear outperformers. - We’re still seeing strong growth in semiconductor (17.7%), industrial robot (17.9%), and service robot (12.8%) production.

We expect core CPI to remain at 3.1% due to another 0.3% m/m reading. Some of the strong services reading in e.g. hotels and airfares might have come down a bit relative to last months. Meanwhile, headline is likely to come in at 0.4% m/m, raising the y/y rate to 3.1% as well. Still, we do not expect these readings to deter the Fed from another 25bps cut in the next meeting.

USD: Dollar softer, but short term trend unclear The dollar is a little softer as short-dated US rates sit at their lows for the year. Last night's release of the Fed's Beige Book suggests the Fed will have enough evidence to cut rates at the end of the month – even if official data releases remain suspended because of the government shutdown. Here, betting markets expect the government to remain closed into November. The hottest topic for financial markets right now is US-China relations ahead of some key dates. Presidents Trump and Xi are meant to be meeting on the sidelines of the APEC summit in Korea in the 29-31 October window. This is before the 10 November deadline for the 90-day truce on tariffs, where no extension would see US tariffs on China revert to 145%.

China CPI inflation edged up but remained in deflation China's CPI inflation edged up in September, but the economy remained in deflation. The main reason is a continued slide in food prices down to -4.4% YoY, a 20-month low. This is, in part, base effect-driven, as MoM prices actually picked up 0.7%. The primary culprit has been pork (-17%), which is currently in a downward trend and likely to continue dragging food inflation for several more months. On a YoY basis, we continued to see notable drags from vegetable (-13.7%), egg (-11.9%), and fruit (-4.2%) prices despite MoM gains for each of these categories. The drag from these categories may persist in October, but should ease from November onward, helping to support a turnaround of food inflation. The silver lining in the data was that non-food inflation picked up to 0.7% YoY, up for a fourth consecutive month despite a -0.1% MoM dip.

meaning: Describes variables that are increasing over time, such as utility bills or risks (e.g., rising utility bills, rising risks to job market).
notes: Standard adjective/participle; no special trading-specific nuance here.
examples: Japan Q3 GDP contracted less than expected: - Japan’s GDP contracted 0.4% qoq in Q3 2025, reversing an upwardly revised 0.6% growth in Q2 but performing slightly better than market expectations of a 0.6% decline, preliminary data showed. - It was the first quarterly drop since Q1 2024, reflecting subdued private consumption (0.1% vs 0.4%) amid lingering cost pressures, particularly elevated rice prices and rising utility bills. - Net trade also contributed negatively (-0.2 ppts), with exports (-1.2% vs 2.3%) falling faster than imports (-0.1% vs 1.3%) after Washington imposed a 15% baseline tariff on most Japanese goods in September. - Still, government spending (0.5% vs 0.1%) and business investment (1.0% vs 0.8%) recorded their strongest gains in five quarters, supported by front-loaded public works and corporate upgrades to production capacity.

Bund yields not reflecting the equities optimism: - Bund yields are falling by more than equities would justify. - From the demand side, we may have more investors seeking safe havens from market turmoil, whilst from a supply perspective, we see very little net issuance in October versus other months. - 10y Bund yield fell to 2.56%, lowest level since July mid, on renewed trade tensions and rising Fed cut bets.

meaning: Refers to exposure to adverse market moves or uncertainty; includes (1) portfolio/position risk that traders manage ('control risk w big size'), and (2) broader market sentiment ('risk off open').

examples: Crypto taking another leg lower now. Sign of risk off open?
Crude is also pretty interesting as supply chains rejigger on Russian sanctions can control risk w big size there

meaning: Past tense of 'rise', used to describe increases in economic indicators (e.g., consumer confidence index rose, expectations rose).
notes: Generic verb; applied to macro data but meaning is standard.
examples: French consumer confidence showed some improvement today. - Consumer confidence in France rose to 90 in October from an upwardly revised 88 in September, marking the highest level since April. - Households were less pessimistic about their financial outlook, with expectations improving to -11 from -14 in September and views on their past situation slightly better at -20 from -21. - Saving sentiment also strengthened, as both current (23 vs 20) and expected (19 vs 17) saving capacity increased, while savings intentions reached a four-month high of 44.

Retail sales in the UK jumped 1.5% YoY in September 2025, accelerating from a 0.7% increase in August and marking the highest gain since April. The GfK Consumer Confidence Index for the UK rose to -17 in October 2025 from -19 in September, beating expectations for a decline to -20 as shoppers geared up for the Black Friday sales despite concerns over the upcoming Budget. The gain was mainly driven by a four-point rise in the major purchase index, which measures confidence in buying big-ticket items, to -12. Expectations for the general economic situation over the next 12 months also climbed two points to -30, while the outlook for personal finances slipped one point to +3.

Eurozone Composite PMI hits 1.5yrs high: - The HCOB Eurozone Composite PMI rose to 52.2 in October of 2025 from 51.2 in the previous month, ahead of market expectations of 51 to reflect the sharpest pace of expansion since May 2024. - The expansion was carried by the services sector (52.6 vs 51.3 in September), which rose to a fresh one-year high, while the manufacturing sector unexpectedly avoided a contraction (50 vs 49.8). - New orders accelerated in the period with strong support from domestic clients, offsetting a fresh drop in export business. - The signals drove firms to increase their staffing levels to erase last month's slight decrease. - Likewise, backlogs of work refrained from dropping from for the first time since April 2023. - Input cost inflation eased for a second month, although output charges accelerated the most in seven. - Looking forward, business confidence waned to a five-month low.

meaning: Used ordinally to denote sequence or count (e.g., 'for a second month', 'second consecutive quarter').
notes: No special financial meaning; purely temporal ordering.

GDP growth slowed by less than expected in 3Q25 - China's GDP grew by 4.8% YoY (missing the5% target) in the third quarter, slowing for a second consecutive quarter from the 5.2% growth in the second quarter. - Still, the economy managed to beat expectations for a steeper decline. - Through the first three quarters of the year, China's economy has grown by 5.2% YoY. - By industry, China's tertiary industry drove growth in 3Q25 with a 5.4% YoY growth, comfortably outpacing growth in the secondary (4.2%) and primary (4.0%) industries. - The better-than-expected GDP data was likely thanks in part to a strong bounce-back in industrial production to 6.5% YoY in September, which is benefiting from resilient external demand. - Yet, soft monthly activity data throughout the quarter suggests that a favourable boost from the GDP deflator may have contributed to this performance.

The most important comment from US Trade Representative Greer Yesterday, we got a strong rebound in the US stock markets. The first 50% of the rally might have started due to CNBC announcing that US Trade Representative Greer would appear on TV. But let's also say that it might have been just a technical dip-buying move as prices fell into the Friday's lows at the cash open. Now, Greer didn't really say anything new but he did deliver two key comments: - We always watch the stock and bond markets. - We want to make sure the market responds to appropriate info. That second comment is key. It sounds like they don't want the market to think this is going to be another April. They want the market to keep expecting a de-escalation.

meaning: Used to indicate expected or previously observed values in data releases (e.g., ‘M/M figure is seen at 0.3%’) or shifts in priorities (‘we have seen a bit of a shift’).
notes: Standard passive/observational usage; in data context it can mean ‘forecasted’ or ‘expected’.
examples: In the US session today, all eyes will be on the September US NFP report and the US Jobless Claims. The NFP is expected at 50K vs 22K prior with the Unemployment Rate remaining unchanged at 4.3%. The Average Hourly Earnings Y/Y is expected at 3.7% vs 3.7% prior, while the M/M figure is seen at 0.3% vs 0.3% prior. Needless to say, this is very old news by now but it might still matter for the market given that we don't get any other NFP report until December 16, which is unfortunately after the December FOMC meeting. The December cut probabilities now stand at just 25% following the update from the BLS that we will get the November NFP only on December 16. We should also get the most recent Jobless Claims data alongside the NFP report, and those might actually be more important. The Initial Claims are expected at 230K, while the Continuing Claims are seen at 1951K.

meaning: Used temporally to mark the last time a condition occurred (e.g., ‘first quarterly drop since Q1 2024’, ‘lowest growth since August 2024’).
notes: Purely temporal; no special financial meaning.
examples: Japan Q3 GDP contracted less than expected: - Japan’s GDP contracted 0.4% qoq in Q3 2025, reversing an upwardly revised 0.6% growth in Q2 but performing slightly better than market expectations of a 0.6% decline, preliminary data showed. - It was the first quarterly drop since Q1 2024, reflecting subdued private consumption (0.1% vs 0.4%) amid lingering cost pressures, particularly elevated rice prices and rising utility bills. - Net trade also contributed negatively (-0.2 ppts), with exports (-1.2% vs 2.3%) falling faster than imports (-0.1% vs 1.3%) after Washington imposed a 15% baseline tariff on most Japanese goods in September. - Still, government spending (0.5% vs 0.1%) and business investment (1.0% vs 0.8%) recorded their strongest gains in five quarters, supported by front-loaded public works and corporate upgrades to production capacity.

China Industrial production came weaker than expected: - October value added of industry growth slowed to 4.9% YoY, down from 6.5%. - This came in below expectations for a smaller decline, marking the lowest growth since August 2024. - The year-to-date growth edged down 0.1pp to 6.1% YoY as a result. - By industry, we continue to see the same themes outperform. - Auto manufacturing (16.8%) and rail, ships, and aeroplane manufacturing (15.2%) remain clear outperformers. - We’re still seeing strong growth in semiconductor (17.7%), industrial robot (17.9%), and service robot (12.8%) production.

French consumer confidence showed some improvement today. - Consumer confidence in France rose to 90 in October from an upwardly revised 88 in September, marking the highest level since April. - Households were less pessimistic about their financial outlook, with expectations improving to -11 from -14 in September and views on their past situation slightly better at -20 from -21. - Saving sentiment also strengthened, as both current (23 vs 20) and expected (19 vs 17) saving capacity increased, while savings intentions reached a four-month high of 44.

meaning: Refers to the notional amount or position size in trades (‘big size’ in crude futures) or the scale of an economy (‘double the size of the economy’).
notes: ‘Size’ as trade notional is trading jargon; macro usage is generic.
examples: Crude is also pretty interesting as supply chains rejigger on Russian sanctions can control risk w big size there

ING: Our first look at the next Five-Year Plan shows China staying the course The communiqué following China's Fourth Plenum has given markets a first look at the priorities for the 15th Five-Year Plan. The key focus for policymakers looks little changed, as modernisation, innovation, self-sufficiency, and boosting domestic demand feature prominently. China's next Five-Year Plan continues to focus on key themes and moderate growth The goal to have per capita GDP reach the level of a "moderately developed economy" was also mentioned, which, in conjunction with previous goals to double the size of the economy between 2020 and 2035, continues to imply an emphasis on maintaining growth of 4-5% in the coming decade. Industrial modernisation, tech self-sufficiency and innovation feature prominently We have seen a bit of a shift in the order of priorities compared to the 14th Five-Year Plan. Following the broader economic and social development targets, building a modern industrial system and strengthening the real economy was the first broad category mentioned, followed by technological self-sufficiency and innovation, and then building a strong domestic market.

Euro rates: Risks around Dutch pension reforms The Dutch central bank acknowledges risks to interest rates linked to the 1 January 2026 transition of Dutch pension funds, but also sees mitigants to prevent market stress. The 10s30s has more room to steepen from a structural perspective, but we don't fully discount the probability of seeing some flattening in January. Dutch pension reforms bring volatility to long end, but market stress unlikely The 10s30s curve has stabilised to around 25bp over the past month, but with the Dutch pension fund reforms on our doorstep, we doubt that stability can hold. The Dutch central bank (DNB) published a piece that highlights the risks to markets given the significant flows anticipated. According to DNB, market analysts anticipate funds will reduce their government bond and swap holdings with maturities of more than 25 years by €100bn to €150bn. Without further specification, DNB suggests that these estimates correspond to approximately the average flows in swap markets for a regular month.

Fourth Plenum, Xi-Trump summit, and PBOC are potential catalysts to watch The stronger-than-expected third-quarter data mean that, barring a dramatic deceleration in 4Q, China will likely manage to reach its full-year target of "around 5%" growth. Domestically, the Fourth Plenum meetings this week are likely to give some insights into China's 15th Five-Year Plan. The full text will not be available until the plan is formally approved at the Two Sessions next year. This plan will offer some insight into how China plans to navigate an increasingly difficult external environment. Investors will likely watch closely for signs of concrete steps to boost consumption, as well as areas for tech development and focus. The long-awaited and high-stakes Xi-Trump meeting next week in South Korea looks likely to take place despite the recent escalations in US-China friction. Language and signalling suggest that both sides would prefer to reach some sort of agreement to continue the current uneasy truce rather than see a re-escalation back to, or beyond, this year's peak tensions in April-May. The odds of miscalculation remain, though, representing a potential downside risk to the outlook. While we see a diminishing marginal impact from further tariff hikes, the prospects of non-tariff escalations represent a notable uncertainty.

meaning: Indicates persistence or continuation of a condition or relevance (e.g., data that ‘might still matter’, ‘still seeing strong growth’).
notes: Generic adverb; no special financial sense.
examples: In the US session today, all eyes will be on the September US NFP report and the US Jobless Claims. The NFP is expected at 50K vs 22K prior with the Unemployment Rate remaining unchanged at 4.3%. The Average Hourly Earnings Y/Y is expected at 3.7% vs 3.7% prior, while the M/M figure is seen at 0.3% vs 0.3% prior. Needless to say, this is very old news by now but it might still matter for the market given that we don't get any other NFP report until December 16, which is unfortunately after the December FOMC meeting. The December cut probabilities now stand at just 25% following the update from the BLS that we will get the November NFP only on December 16. We should also get the most recent Jobless Claims data alongside the NFP report, and those might actually be more important. The Initial Claims are expected at 230K, while the Continuing Claims are seen at 1951K.

Eurozone Composite PMI hits 1.5yrs high: - The HCOB Eurozone Composite PMI rose to 52.2 in October of 2025 from 51.2 in the previous month, ahead of market expectations of 51 to reflect the sharpest pace of expansion since May 2024. - The expansion was carried by the services sector (52.6 vs 51.3 in September), which rose to a fresh one-year high, while the manufacturing sector unexpectedly avoided a contraction (50 vs 49.8). - New orders accelerated in the period with strong support from domestic clients, offsetting a fresh drop in export business. - The signals drove firms to increase their staffing levels to erase last month's slight decrease. - Likewise, backlogs of work refrained from dropping from for the first time since April 2023. - Input cost inflation eased for a second month, although output charges accelerated the most in seven. - Looking forward, business confidence waned to a five-month low.

We expect core CPI to remain at 3.1% due to another 0.3% m/m reading. Some of the strong services reading in e.g. hotels and airfares might have come down a bit relative to last months. Meanwhile, headline is likely to come in at 0.4% m/m, raising the y/y rate to 3.1% as well. Still, we do not expect these readings to deter the Fed from another 25bps cut in the next meeting.

GDP growth slowed by less than expected in 3Q25 - China's GDP grew by 4.8% YoY (missing the5% target) in the third quarter, slowing for a second consecutive quarter from the 5.2% growth in the second quarter. - Still, the economy managed to beat expectations for a steeper decline. - Through the first three quarters of the year, China's economy has grown by 5.2% YoY. - By industry, China's tertiary industry drove growth in 3Q25 with a 5.4% YoY growth, comfortably outpacing growth in the secondary (4.2%) and primary (4.0%) industries. - The better-than-expected GDP data was likely thanks in part to a strong bounce-back in industrial production to 6.5% YoY in September, which is benefiting from resilient external demand. - Yet, soft monthly activity data throughout the quarter suggests that a favourable boost from the GDP deflator may have contributed to this performance.

USD: Dollar softer, but short term trend unclear The dollar is a little softer as short-dated US rates sit at their lows for the year. Last night's release of the Fed's Beige Book suggests the Fed will have enough evidence to cut rates at the end of the month – even if official data releases remain suspended because of the government shutdown. Here, betting markets expect the government to remain closed into November. The hottest topic for financial markets right now is US-China relations ahead of some key dates. Presidents Trump and Xi are meant to be meeting on the sidelines of the APEC summit in Korea in the 29-31 October window. This is before the 10 November deadline for the 90-day truce on tariffs, where no extension would see US tariffs on China revert to 145%.

meaning: Refers to a desired or forecast price level or macro objective (e.g., gold price ‘target’ range, GDP growth ‘target’ of around 5%).
notes: In markets, ‘target’ is standard for price/level objectives or policy goals.
examples: Historically, gold’s share in large institutional and sovereign portfolios has remained remarkably stable — typically in the range of 8–12% for diversified funds and 3–5% for traditional multi-asset portfolios. Despite major macro shifts over the past decade — from negative interest rates to post-pandemic tightening — the structural allocation to gold has not changed materially. However, the current global investment climate presents a notably different backdrop: • Elevated geopolitical uncertainty (U.S.–China trade realignments, Middle East tensions, and rising nuclear risk rhetoric) • Persistently high fiscal deficits across major economies, leading to currency debasement fears • Increasing volatility in both equity and bond markets due to diverging monetary policies • Declining real yields and renewed expectations of monetary easing in 2026 Given these factors, even a marginal portfolio realignment — an increase of just 2–5% in gold allocation — across institutional or high-net-worth portfolios could generate significant incremental demand. For context, every 1% shift in global asset allocation toward gold represents hundreds of tonnes of additional demand, which historically has had a multiplicative price impact due to the market’s limited float and thin elasticity. Estimated target for end-2025 Putting all this together, a reasonable base-case target could be in the US $4,200-$4,600/oz range by end-2025, assuming no major shock.

Bund yields not reflecting the equities optimism: - Bund yields are falling by more than equities would justify. - From the demand side, we may have more investors seeking safe havens from market turmoil, whilst from a supply perspective, we see very little net issuance in October versus other months. - 10y Bund yield fell to 2.56%, lowest level since July mid, on renewed trade tensions and rising Fed cut bets.

Side note- Euro rates in the shadow of US-driven global sentiment Trade tensions have forced 10Y US Treasury yields below 4% again. The spillovers to euro rates remain moderate, but a broader global risk-off episode would likely force 10Y rates to explore lower ranges. Bunds, especially, could see high demand in such scenarios as one of the last remaining AAA havens.

Estimated target for end-2025 Putting all this together, a reasonable base-case target could be in the US $4,200-$4,600/oz range by end-2025, assuming no major shock.

meaning: Used both as macro ‘net trade’ (exports minus imports contributing to GDP) and as the act of transacting in assets (broader context of trade realignments).
notes: In this corpus, primarily macro/trade-balance and trade-policy sense, but overlaps with generic ‘to trade’ securities.
examples: Japan Q3 GDP contracted less than expected: - Japan’s GDP contracted 0.4% qoq in Q3 2025, reversing an upwardly revised 0.6% growth in Q2 but performing slightly better than market expectations of a 0.6% decline, preliminary data showed. - It was the first quarterly drop since Q1 2024, reflecting subdued private consumption (0.1% vs 0.4%) amid lingering cost pressures, particularly elevated rice prices and rising utility bills. - Net trade also contributed negatively (-0.2 ppts), with exports (-1.2% vs 2.3%) falling faster than imports (-0.1% vs 1.3%) after Washington imposed a 15% baseline tariff on most Japanese goods in September. - Still, government spending (0.5% vs 0.1%) and business investment (1.0% vs 0.8%) recorded their strongest gains in five quarters, supported by front-loaded public works and corporate upgrades to production capacity.

meaning: Used as an intensifier to emphasize the degree of a statement (e.g., how old the news is, how little issuance there is).

examples: In the US session today, all eyes will be on the September US NFP report and the US Jobless Claims. French consumer confidence showed some improvement today. - Consumer confidence in France rose to 90 in October from an upwardly revised 88 in September, marking the highest level since April. - Households were less pessimistic about their financial outlook, with expectations improving to -11 from -14 in September and views on their past situation slightly better at -20 from -21. - Saving sentiment also strengthened, as both current (23 vs 20) and expected (19 vs 17) saving capacity increased, while savings intentions reached a four-month high of 44.

meaning: Used in the ordinary sense of desiring an outcome or objective, such as policymakers wanting markets to respond appropriately or not to expect escalation.
notes: No special trading meaning here.
examples: The most important comment from US Trade Representative Greer Yesterday, we got a strong rebound in the US stock markets. The first 50% of the rally might have started due to CNBC announcing that US Trade Representative Greer would appear on TV. But let's also say that it might have been just a technical dip-buying move as prices fell into the Friday's lows at the cash open. Now, Greer didn't really say anything new but he did deliver two key comments: - We always watch the stock and bond markets. - We want to make sure the market responds to appropriate info. That second comment is key. It sounds like they don't want the market to think this is going to be another April. They want the market to keep expecting a de-escalation.

meaning: To monitor closely for market-relevant developments, such as catalysts, data releases, or market moves.
notes: Generic verb; in trading it implies active monitoring for trading impact.
examples: Fourth Plenum, Xi-Trump summit, and PBOC are potential catalysts to watch The stronger-than-expected third-quarter data mean that, barring a dramatic deceleration in 4Q, China will likely manage to reach its full-year target of "around 5%" growth. Domestically, the Fourth Plenum meetings this week are likely to give some insights into China's 15th Five-Year Plan. The full text will not be available until the plan is formally approved at the Two Sessions next year. This plan will offer some insight into how China plans to navigate an increasingly difficult external environment. Investors will likely watch closely for signs of concrete steps to boost consumption, as well as areas for tech development and focus. The long-awaited and high-stakes Xi-Trump meeting next week in South Korea looks likely to take place despite the recent escalations in US-China friction. Language and signalling suggest that both sides would prefer to reach some sort of agreement to continue the current uneasy truce rather than see a re-escalation back to, or beyond, this year's peak tensions in April-May. The odds of miscalculation remain, though, representing a potential downside risk to the outlook. While we see a diminishing marginal impact from further tariff hikes, the prospects of non-tariff escalations represent a notable uncertainty.

Eurozone Composite PMI hits 1.5yrs high: - The HCOB Eurozone Composite PMI rose to 52.2 in October of 2025 from 51.2 in the previous month, ahead of market expectations of 51 to reflect the sharpest pace of expansion since May 2024. - The expansion was carried by the services sector (52.6 vs 51.3 in September), which rose to a fresh one-year high, while the manufacturing sector unexpectedly avoided a contraction (50 vs 49.8). - New orders accelerated in the period with strong support from domestic clients, offsetting a fresh drop in export business. - The signals drove firms to increase their staffing levels to erase last month's slight decrease. - Likewise, backlogs of work refrained from dropping from for the first time since April 2023. - Input cost inflation eased for a second month, although output charges accelerated the most in seven. - Looking forward, business confidence waned to a five-month low.

Euro rates: Risks around Dutch pension reforms The Dutch central bank acknowledges risks to interest rates linked to the 1 January 2026 transition of Dutch pension funds, but also sees mitigants to prevent market stress. The 10s30s has more room to steepen from a structural perspective, but we don't fully discount the probability of seeing some flattening in January. Dutch pension reforms bring volatility to long end, but market stress unlikely The 10s30s curve has stabilised to around 25bp over the past month, but with the Dutch pension fund reforms on our doorstep, we doubt that stability can hold. The Dutch central bank (DNB) published a piece that highlights the risks to markets given the significant flows anticipated. According to DNB, market analysts anticipate funds will reduce their government bond and swap holdings with maturities of more than 25 years by €100bn to €150bn. Without further specification, DNB suggests that these estimates correspond to approximately the average flows in swap markets for a regular month.

USD: Dollar softer, but short term trend unclear The dollar is a little softer as short-dated US rates sit at their lows for the year. Last night's release of the Fed's Beige Book suggests the Fed will have enough evidence to cut rates at the end of the month – even if official data releases remain suspended because of the government shutdown. Here, betting markets expect the government to remain closed into November. The hottest topic for financial markets right now is US-China relations ahead of some key dates. Presidents Trump and Xi are meant to be meeting on the sidelines of the APEC summit in Korea in the 29-31 October window. This is before the 10 November deadline for the 90-day truce on tariffs, where no extension would see US tariffs on China revert to 145%.
